user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SymbolLookup_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SymbolLookup_Impl(cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    int32            status;
    int32            local_status;
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    /* First search global table */
    status = OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(OSAL_DLSYM_DEFAULT_HANDLE, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);

    /* If not found iterate through module local symbols and break if found */
    if (status != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE, &iter);
        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            local_status = OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(&iter.token, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);
            if (local_status == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                status = local_status;
                break;
            }
        }
        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SymbolLookup_Impl:
int32 OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(void *dl_handle, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    const char *dlError; /*  Pointer to error string   */
    void *      Function;
    int32       status;

    status = OS_ERROR;

    /*
     * call dlerror() to clear any prior error that might have occurred.
     */
    dlerror();
    Function = dlsym(dl_handle, SymbolName);
    dlError  = dlerror();

    /*
     * For the POSIX DL implementation, if the symbol does not exist
     * then dlerror() is supposed to return non-null.  This is intended
     * to differentiate between valid symbols which are actually 0/NULL
     * and invalid symbols that do not exist.
     *
     * Some implementations do _not_ implement this detail, and dlerror()
     * still returns NULL after looking up an invalid symbol name.
     *
     * In practice, this is expected to be used for looking up functions
     * and as such all valid symbols should be non-NULL, so NULL is considered
     * an error even if the C library doesn't consider this an error.
     */
    if (dlError != NULL)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: %s: %s\n", SymbolName, dlError);
    }
    else if (Function == NULL)
    {
        /* technically not an error per POSIX, but in practice should not happen */
        OS_DEBUG("Error: %s: dlsym() returned NULL\n", SymbolName);
    }
    else
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    *SymbolAddress = (cpuaddr)Function;

    return status;
}
...
int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    int32                             status;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    status = OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(impl->dl_handle, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);

    return status;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(osal_objtype_t objtype, OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectFilterActive, NULL, objtype, iter);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OSAL_DLSYM_DEFAULT_HANDLE NULL
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Analysis by function:

- OS_SymbolLookup_Impl: does not assign to its parameters (SymbolAddress, SymbolName). It only passes these pointers to other functions; the pointer variables themselves are not modified.

- OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl: writes to *SymbolAddress (via *SymbolAddress = (cpuaddr)Function;). This modifies the object pointed to by the pointer parameter, which is explicitly allowed by the rule. The pointer parameter SymbolAddress itself is not reassigned.

- OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl: uses the const pointer token by dereferencing (*token) to index a table and passes SymbolAddress and SymbolName through; it does not assign to any parameter variables.

- OS_ObjectIdIterateActive: simply calls an initializer with the iter pointer; it does not modify its parameter variables.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext: modifies contents of the object pointed to by iter (e.g., iter->token.obj_id, iter->token.obj_idx). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is allowed; the function does not reassign the iter pointer itself.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy: calls OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token) and does not modify the iter parameter variable.

Other symbols/macros (OSAL_DLSYM_DEFAULT_HANDLE, OS_SUCCESS, etc.) do not affect parameter modification.

Therefore there are no assignments to function parameter variables (no reassignments of pointer parameters), and all observed writes are to objects pointed to by pointer parameters, which is permitted by Rule 17.8. No fragments need further investigation.
